gen.metadata.authors: DiCarlofelice, A.; E.D.; A.D.; P.T.; DiGiampaolo, E.; Tognolatti, P.
gen.metadata.title: A Numerical Procedure to Design a UWB Aperture-Coupled Microstrip Antenna Suitable for Space Applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To develop a design procedure for a dual-polarized ultra-wideband ACMA suitable for CubeSat applications, with a focus on minimizing construction complexity and costs (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve good agreement between simulation and measurement results (p. 11); Develop a simple layered structure without inter-layer interconnects (p. 11); Ensure the design is suitable for large-scale production by minimizing construction complexity (p. 1); Design an ACMA with a fractional bandwidth > 40%, return loss > 10 dB, and polarization purity and isolation > 25 dB (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Further investigation into the impact of manufacturing imperfections and material properties (p. 9); Explore the use of different materials and manufacturing techniques to further optimize performance and cost (p. 1); Investigate the application of the design procedure to other frequency bands (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use the developed design procedure for creating ACMA for CubeSat applications (p. 1); Consider the use of simple multilayer structures without interlayer interconnections or inclusions to minimize costs (p. 1); Use the design procedure for cost-effective mass production of antennae for CubeSats (p. 11)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for a dual-polarized ultra-wideband aperture-coupled microstrip antenna (ACMA) suitable for CubeSat Ka-band applications, with a focus on minimizing construction complexity and costs (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a dual-polarized ultra-wideband ACMA be designed for CubeSat applications with minimal construction complexity and cost? (p. 1); What design procedure can achieve the required performance metrics (fractional bandwidth > 40%, return loss > 10 dB, polarization purity and isolation > 25 dB) using simple technology? (p. 1); How can a simple layered structure without inter-layer interconnects be developed for dual-polarized ultra-wideband aperture-coupled microstrip antennae? (p. 11)
esp.domain_methodology.measurement_condi: 11.9 m × 5.6 m × 6.0 m anechoic chamber using the multi-probe system Starlab and other microwave facilities at MVG Italia (p. 8)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Ansys HFSS optimizer using sequential non-linear programming (SNLP) (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers RT6002 (ϵr = 2.94, tanδ = 0.0012) for dielectric 1, RO4003 (ϵr = 3.55, tanδ = 0.0021) for dielectrics 2 and 3 (p. 5)
esp.technical_specifications.substrate_m: Rogers RT6002 for dielectric 1, RO4003 for dielectrics 2 and 3 (p. 5)

gen.metadata.authors: Johnson, A.; Volakis, J. L.; Manohar, V.; Alexander D. Johnson; Satheesh Bojja Venkatakrishnan; Venkatakrishnan, S. B.; Vignesh Manohar; John L. Volakis
gen.metadata.title: Low-Cost S-Band Reconfigurable Monopole/Patch Antenna for CubeSats
gen.objectives.main_objective: To present a reconfigurable antenna concept for CubeSats that can operate in both patch and monopole states, reducing weight, cost, and power consumption (p. 5)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Design an antenna that can switch between patch and monopole modes using adhesive polyimide tapes (p. 1); Evaluate the performance of the antenna in both modes (p. 1); Design and fabricate a reconfigurable antenna (p. 5); Measure and compare the performance metrics of the antenna in both states (p. 5)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the use of high-fidelity servo motors for actuation in full-framed 6U CubeSats (p. 3); Investigation of the antenna's performance in other frequency bands (p. 5)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use adhesive polyimide tapes for reconfigurable antenna designs in CubeSats (p. 1); Further studies on antenna space qualification for specific applications (p. 5)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Designing reconfigurable antennas for CubeSats is challenging due to mechanical constraints and limited power, but such antennas are needed for multi-functional radars and communications (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: What are the performance metrics of the reconfigurable antenna in both modes? (p. 1); How can a reconfigurable antenna be designed to switch between patch and monopole modes? (p. 1); What are the performance metrics of the reconfigurable antenna in both states? (p. 5); How can a reconfigurable antenna be designed to operate in both patch and monopole states? (p. 5)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: HFSS FEM method and QNM package (p. 2)
esp.domain_results.bandwidth: 6.9% with S11 < −10 dB in patch state, 2.6% with S11 < −10 dB in monopole state (p. 5)
esp.domain_results.gain: Patch mode: 7.7 dBi, Monopole mode: 1.2 dBi (p. 4)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Patch mode: Maximum radiation along θ = 0°, Monopole mode: Maximum radiation near θ = 90° (p. 3)
esp.domain_results.return_loss: Patch mode: S11 < −10 dB, Monopole mode: S11 < −10 dB (p. 4)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers Arlon DiClad 880 (ϵr = 2.2, h = 3.175 mm), copper tape, polyimide tape (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Microstrip line etched on the top of the substrate and copper tape for the patch geometry (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.polarizatio: Patch mode: ˆφ polarized along the φ = 0° plane, Monopole mode: ˆθ polarized (p. 3)

gen.metadata.authors: Rao Shahid Aziz; Anna Pietrenko-Dabrowska; Slawomir Koziel
gen.metadata.title: A compact tri-band omnidirectional antenna design for CubeSat applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design a compact tri-band omnidirectional antenna for CubeSat applications that operates at UHF, L-band, and S-band, and can be fully enclosed within the CubeSat (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Ensure omnidirectional radiation patterns across all frequency bands (p. 1); Achieve multi-band resonance and high radiation efficiency (p. 14); Achieve stable multi-band resonance (p. 1); Compare the performance of the proposed antenna with existing CubeSat antennas (p. 14); Not mentioned; Ensure high radiation efficiency (p. 1); Ensure the antenna is fully enclosed within the CubeSat without external deployment (p. 14); Maintain a small footprint (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the performance of the antenna in different CubeSat configurations (p. 2); Explore the integration of the antenna with other CubeSat components for enhanced functionality (p. 14); Explore the use of advanced materials to further enhance antenna performance (p. 2); Not mentioned; Investigate the performance of the antenna in different environmental conditions (p. 14)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Integrate the proposed antenna design in future CubeSat missions (p. 2); Not mentioned; Utilize 3D-printed plastic materials for CubeSat construction to reduce weight and cost (p. 2); Integrate the proposed antenna design into CubeSat platforms for improved communication systems (p. 14)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The challenge of designing a compact, multi-band, omnidirectional antenna for CubeSat applications that can be fully enclosed within the CubeSat, ensuring easy integration and mechanical robustness (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: What are the key design features that enable stable multi-band resonance and omnidirectional radiation patterns? (p. 1); Not mentioned; How can a compact tri-band omnidirectional antenna be designed for 1U CubeSat applications? (p. 14); How can a compact tri-band omnidirectional antenna be designed for CubeSat applications? (p. 1); What are the performance metrics of the proposed antenna compared to existing designs? (p. 14)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: The proposed design offers enhanced stability, compact size, and ease of deployment within a CubeSat compared to other published antenna designs (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.frequency_b: UHF (0.755 GHz), L-band (1.25 GHz), S-band (2.28 to 3.74 GHz) (p. 14)
